The metallosilicate catalysts (H-M-silicate, when M = Al, Fe, Cu, and Ni and Si/metal = 20) were synthesized and characterized by XRD, SEM-EDX, XRF, N2 adsorption and desorption, 27Al MAS NMR, XANES, EXAFS, NH3-TPD, NH3-IR, and TPO methods to investigate the effect of transition metals substitution in zeolite structure for 1-butene reaction. Only Fe3+ of H-Fe-silicate bonded in the MFI structure like H-ZSM-5, whereas transition metals of H-Cu-silicate and H-Ni-silicate embedded in zeolite matrix over catalyst surface; therefore: the reduction reaction occurred over metal of H-M-silicate catalyst during the reaction. There were two different roles of Brønsted acid site, detected by NH3-IR (B1 at ca. 1470 cm−1 and B2 at ca. 1660 cm−1). The B1 Brønsted acid site over micropore surface of catalyst (Si-OH-M) favored oligomerization-cracking route of 1-butene reaction, while butene isomerization route reacted on B2 Brønsted acid site (Si-OH) over external surface of catalyst (Acid strength: B1 > B2) Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Brønsted acid site Metallosilicate 1-butene Oligomerization-cracking Butene isomerization Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Currently, the catalytic cracking of many different hydrocarbon reactions has been deeply studied to understand the reaction mechanism and enhance the production of desired products in various applications [1,2]; therefore: various catalyst types have been investigated [3–6]. However, H-ZSM-5 (MFI structure), a solid-acid catalyst, is one of the most suitable catalysts for this reaction because of its proper properties, physical and chemical properties [7–9]. And the catalytic cracking of hydrocarbon reaction including butene cracking reaction generally requires an acid site (Brønsted acid site) over catalyst surface to continue the cracking mechanism [10–12]; therefore: the solid-acid catalyst with different acid strength is a key to control product distribution from the reaction. The Brønsted acid site, detected by pyridine-IR, is an active site for butene cracking reaction [13] because a proton from the Brønsted acid site is protonated to 1-butene (reactant) to form carbenium ion, and then various types of reaction can further occur. The 1-butene cracking reaction is one of the complicated reaction mechanisms because various types of product have been generated under different reaction pathways associating with isomerization, oligomerization, cracking, hydrogen transfer, and aromatization [13]. Generally, the Brønsted acid site, detected by pyridine-IR, relates with only one peak at 1540 cm−1 [14,15], and this result is a limitation of pyridine-IR which is not identify more deeply in Brønsted acid site of the catalyst. However, the Brønsted acid site, detected by NH3-IR, is associated with two bands at 1470, and 1660 cm−1 [16,17], and a molecule of ammonia is smaller than pyridine molecule. Therefore, to profoundly investigate the role of Brønsted acid site over the catalyst surface, the NH3-IR technique should be applied to study the role of each type of Brønsted acid site to promote different product distribution for 1-butene cracking reaction. Based on literature, H-M-silicate (M-MFI, M = transition metals) with low Si/metal molar ratio was proposed to apply with various reaction applications because the number of active site was modified [18]. However, the H-M-silicate has not been widely investigated in hydrocarbon cracking reaction and there is some lacking information about the role of each Brønsted acid type in 1-butene cracking reaction to control the product distribution. Therefore, examining the role of each Brønsted acid type in metallosilicate catalyst with high metal content is a crucial point to understand product formation mechanism in different route, which is useful information for catalyst development in hydrocarbon reaction. In this study, H-M-silicate (M = Al (H-ZSM-5), Fe, Cu, and Ni) with Si/metal molar ratio = 20 were synthesized by rapid crystallization method to investigate the effect of metal in zeolite structure and the role of acidity for product distribution in 1-butene cracking reaction. XRD profile applied to identity catalyst structure of fresh and spent samples. SEM image was applied to characterize a morphology of catalyst and metal element on catalyst surface was determined by EDX technique. The metal content in catalyst bulk was identified by XRF technique. N2 adsorption and desorption identified the surface area and pore volume of H-M-silicate. 27Al MAS NMR technique used to characterize aluminum species of H-ZSM-5 catalyst, whereas XANES and EXAFS results presented type of metal coordination and local coordination environment of the sample for H-M-silicate catalyst (M = Fe, Cu, and Ni). The intensity of each Brønsted and Lewis acid types was investigated by NH3-IR and acid strength of all synthesized sample was studied by NH3-TPD. TPO technique used to examine percentage of carbon content of spent catalyst after reaction testing. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation Metallosilicate catalysts (H-Al-silicate or H-ZSM-5, H-Fe-silicate, H-Cu-silicate, and H-Ni-silicate) with Si/metal molar ratio = 20 were synthesized by rapid crystallization method [19]. Metal sources of aluminum, iron, copper, and nickel were Al2(SO4)3·18H2O (UNIVAR), Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (Sigma-Aldrich), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (Sigma-Aldrich), and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich), respectively. Silica source was sodium silicate solution (MERCK) and tetrapropylammonium bromide (Sigma-Aldrich) used to be a template of the synthesized catalyst in this study. All elements were stirred and mixed, then transfer to an autoclave for crystallization process. During the hydrothermal treatment, the temperature ramped into 160 °C (60 °C/h) for 2 h, and then it increased to final temperature at 210 °C (10 °C/h) for 5 h. Deionized water used to rinse a crystal catalyst until pH = 7.0. Subsequently, the wet sample was moved into an oven overnight, then dried sample was calcined with air stream at 550 °C. Afterward, sodium form of metallosilicate (Na-M-silicate, M = Al, Fe, Cu, and Ni) was observed. Na-M-silicate was ion-exchanged with 1 M NH4NO3 solution at 80 °C for 2 h to transfer Na+ ion to NH4 + ion. Next, NH4 −M-silicate was washed, dried, and calcined as same as the method that mentioned above. Finally, H-M-silicate (M = Al, Fe, Cu, and Ni) was appeared. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction, XRD, provided information about crystalline phase identification and crystal structure of synthesized catalyst sample. The XRD pattern was recorded at the angle 2-THETA between from 5° to 50° (Step size: 0.01) on a Bruker AXS D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Ni-filtered CuKα radiation. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) image is analyzed by a Hitachi Model S-3400 N and the metal element on catalyst surface is identified by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) with Link Isis Series 300 program. The metal element of catalyst bulk was identified by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) technique with a Bruker S8 TIGER. The 27Al MAS NMR technique was used to characterize type of aluminum site by Fourier Transform Nuclear Magnetic Resonance spectrometer 400 MHz. (Solid) instrument with a Bruker AVANCE III HD (Ascend 400 WB) and the spectrometer equipment was 4 mm diameter rotor, 8 kHz of speed rate, and 400.20 MHz of resonance frequency. N2 adsorption and desorption characterization presented the information to identify the catalyst surface area and pore volume under BET and t-plot methods, respectively. A Micromeritics 3Flex3500 multipoint gas adsorption, which was a high throughput surface area and pore characterization analyzer, was applied in this method at 196.15 °C. The degassing process started at 90 °C in vacuum for 1 h, then the temperature increased to 150 °C for 4 h. X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS) were used to identify oxidation state, symmetry, and local coordination environment of the samples. XANES and EXAFS techniques of the Fe, Cu and Ni K-edge were performed for 6 samples (Fresh and spent H-Fe-silicate, H-Cu-silicate, and H-Ni-silicate) at Beamline 1.1 W (Multiple X-ray Techniques), Synchrotron Light Research Institute (Public Organization), Thailand, respectively. The experiment was operated at ambient pressure and temperature. Furthermore, the Fe K-edge (Fe(0), FeO, and Fe2O3), the Cu K-edge (Cu(0), CuO, Cu2O, and Cu(OAc)2), and the Ni K-edge (Ni(0), NiO, and NiO2) were also used to be a standard reference for H-Fe-silicate, H-Cu-silicate, and H-Ni-silicate, respectively. The data reporting in transmission mode (E-space, E-space 1st derivatives, K-space Comparison, R-space, and linear combination fitting of each metal oxide phase) were determined by using Athena software [20]. Temperature programmed desorption of ammonia was a widely useful technique to determine acid site densities under a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2750 automated system. First, 0.1 g of sample was weighted and moved into a quartz U-tube, then sample was preheated at 550 °C for 1 h (He gas stream = 25 ml/min). After cooling the sample to 40 °C, it was adsorbed with ammonia gas stream for half an hour (15% NH3/He mixed gas stream = 25 ml/min). Subsequently, the physisorption of ammonia molecules was evacuated by a He gas stream under 25 ml/min of flow rate. Finally, the signal of temperature increasing from 40 to 600 °C with 10 °C/min of heating rate was linearly recorded by TCD detector. The ammonia was also used as probe molecules for Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) to identify the number of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites over the sample. First, 0.2 g of sample was transferred to the in-situ IR cell with a KBr window under close circulating system. The pretreatment step at 550 °C (10 °C/min) for 1 h (N2 gas stream = 10 ml/min) was applied, and then the temperature was cooled down to 40 °C to record the signal (a pretreatment signal, OH stretching band). Subsequently, the pretreated sample was adsorbed with ammonia gas stream for half an hour (15% NH3/He mixed gas stream = 15 ml/min). Next, the physisorbed ammonia was evacuated at 40 °C for 1 h (N2 gas stream = 10 ml/min). Afterwards, the signal was recorded again at 40 °C and it was subtracted with the pretreatment signal to determine Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. The recorded signal after the pretreatment step was used to identify the OH stretching region over catalyst surface. Temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) was used to analyze coke content after the reaction and TPO profile was identified by a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2750 automated system. A gas chromatography with Rt-Q-BOND—Fused Silica Plot column was used to detect CO2 formation. First, 0.05 g of used sample was moved into a quartz U-tube under oxygen gas stream (1% O2/He mixed gas stream = 25 ml/min). For the signal, the oxidation temperature increasing from room temperature to 970 °C with 10 °C/min of heating rate was linearly recorded by TCD detector. 2.3 Catalyst testing The catalytic testing of 1-butene reaction was operated with a fixed-bed tubular reactor made of stainless steel, 19.05 mm of inner reactor diameter, with a K-type thermocouple. For the reaction testing step, 1 g of synthesized catalyst sample was packed and moved into the reactor to preheat with N2 gas stream for 1 h at 550 °C, and then the temperature was decreased into reaction temperature at 500 °C under atmospheric pressure. The weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of the reactant gas at 3 h − 1 with 65:35 of molar composition reactant gas between butene (≥99.5% purity) and N2 (99.999% purity). The specification of a gas chromatography to evaluate the product compositions was an Agilent J&W HP-PLOT Al2O3 S with FID detector. The 1-butene conversion, product selectivity, and catalyst deactivation were determined and presented in the supplementary information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst structural properties XRD patterns of fresh and spent H-M-silicate catalysts display in supplementary material Fig. S1. Fresh synthesized H-M-silicate catalysts present a typical MFI structure like ZSM-5 [21,22], but different peak intensity (especially in the range between 7° and 10°). H-Cu-silicate and H-Ni-silicate presented higher peak intensity in the range of 7–10°, whereas H-Fe-silicate displayed lower intensity of these peaks when compared with H-ZSM-5 catalyst. After testing 1-butene reaction, all samples also retained a typical MFI structure like fresh catalyst. This result suggested that 1-butene reaction did not destroy the MFI structure of the catalyst. The SEM image of H-M-silicate catalyst presents in supplementary material Fig. S2 and it revealed that the morphology of H-M-silicate catalysts (M = Fe, Cu, and Ni) are a uniform spherical shape of catalyst particles like ZSM-5 catalyst [23]. The number of Si/metal atomic ratio over H-M-silicate catalyst is a little bit different with the Si/Al atomic ratio over H-ZSM-5 as present in Table 1 . The group of Na-M-silicate catalyst presented the higher number of Na+ ion in the catalyst structure when compared with the group of H-M-silicate, characterized by XRF as shown in supplementary material table 1. This result confirmed that the ion-exchange process to transform Na+ to H+ ion occurred for metallosilicate catalysts (Metal = Fe, Cu, and Ni) as same as ZSM-5 catalyst. The lower Na content for metallosilicate catalysts (Metal = Fe, Cu, and Ni) when compared with ZSM-5 implied that transition metals inhibited Na+ ion to bond in bulk catalyst during the catalyst synthesis. The surface area and pore volume of H-M-silicate catalyst are presented and summarized in supplementary material Fig. S3 and Table 1, respectively. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms on H-M-silicate catalyst corresponded with type I isotherm (microporous) [24,25] as presented in supplementary material Fig. S3. The BET surface area ranking was H-ZSM-5, H-Fe-silicate, H-Ni-silicate, and H-Cu-silicate, respectively (in order of highest to lowest value). The H-ZSM-5 and H-Fe-silicate displayed a higher of micropore surface area when compared with external surface area of these catalysts. While H-Cu-silicate and H-Ni-silicate had a higher external surface area than micropore surface area of these catalysts. The total pore volume of H-M-silicate was in the range between 0.17 and 0.19 cm−3/g. For H-ZSM-5 and H-Fe-silicate, the majority of catalyst pore structure was micropore volume. Whereas H-Cu-silicate and H-Ni-silicate preferred to form mesopore volume. aluminum species of fresh and spent H-ZSM-5 structure depicts in Fig. 1 . The peaks at ca. 55, 30, and 0 ppm are associated with tetrahedral, pentahedral, and octahedral framework Al sites in zeolite structure [26,27]. Based on Fig. 1, the fresh synthesized H-ZSM-5 appeared one main peak and one small peak relating with tetrahedral and octahedral framework Al sites (ca. 55, and 0 ppm), respectively. The spent H-ZSM-5 catalyst also observed tetrahedral and octahedral framework Al sites like fresh H-ZSM-5 catalyst, but it displayed different intensity of Al sites (lower tetrahedral framework Al site and higher octahedral framework Al site when compared with fresh H-ZSM-5). This result confirmed that the dealumination process occurred to deactivate the catalyst during the reaction because it broke the Si-O-Al bond which was one of the active sites for butene reaction [14] and form Si-O-Si bond [28]. The pentahedral framework Al sites could not detect in fresh and spent H-ZSM-5 catalysts as shown in Fig. 1. For XANES and EXAFS results, the spectra of normalized E-space, normalized 1st derivatives E-space, K-space comparison, and R-space for fresh and spent H-Fe-silicate, H-Cu-silicate, and H-Ni-silicate display in Fig. 2 . The percentage of each metal oxide phase over fresh and spent H-Cu-silicate and H-Ni-silicate were identified by linear combination fitting (LCF) as summarized in Table 2 . The XANES and EXAFS patterns of fresh H-Fe-silicate as shown in Fig. 2a) was quite different with the standard metal references (Fe(0), FeO, and Fe2O3) and a pre-edge peak of fresh H-Fe-silicate clearly appeared. While the 1st derivative E-space of fresh H-Fe-silicate was quite similar with a Fe2O3 standard reference as displayed in Fig. 2d). However, the R-space result of fresh H-Fe-silicate (Fig. 2j)) corresponded with the Fe2O3 standard reference (supplementary material Fig. S4a); therefore: it confirmed that the role of iron metal (Fe3+) could be substitute in the MFI structure during catalyst synthesis process like role of aluminum metal (Al3+) in H-ZSM-5 catalyst because the second shell coordination of fresh H-Fe-silicate (radial distance = 2–3 Å) dropped a lot when compared with the first shell and it was absolutely different from Fe2O3 standard reference. This result implied that no iron metal detected surrounding the first shell which was an oxygen (radial distance = 1–2 Å); therefore: the iron metal should be bonded in MFI structure of the catalyst. After reaction testing, the E-space pattern of spent H-Fe-silicate shifted to more Fe2+ oxidation state when compared with the fresh H-Fe-silicate as shown in Fig. 2a) and d). For R-space profile, the amplitude of spent H-Fe-silicate was lower than fresh H-Fe-silicate as demonstrated in Fig. 2j). This result suggested the total coordination number of spent H-Fe-silicate decreased after testing 1-butene reaction. The K-space combination of fresh and spent H-Fe-silicate as displayed in Fig. 2g) confirmed that the iron phase did not changed during the reaction testing because of same oscillation pattern. For the H-Cu-silicate and H-Ni-silicate catalysts, their XANES and EXAFS results were different from H-Fe-silicate catalyst results. The fresh H-Cu-silicate was quite similar with the standard reference of CuO metal oxide as presented in Fig. 2b) and e). This result implied that copper metal did not bond in MFI structure, however the metal was embedded in zeolite matrix over the catalyst surface. The percentage of Cu(0), CuO, Cu2O, and Cu(OAc)2 over fresh H-Cu-silicate was 1.40, 84.70, 1.10, and 12.70, respectively as shown in Table 2. However, the oxidation state of spent H-Cu-silicate was different from fresh H-Cu-silicate and the detailed fraction of copper oxides was 45.50% of Cu(0), 23.30% of CuO, 30.70% of Cu2O, and 1.60% of Cu(OAc)2. This result implied that there was a reduction reaction over metal oxide (H-Cu-silicate) during 1-butene reaction testing. The dissimilar of K-space oscillation and R-space pattern between fresh and spent H-Cu-silicate endorsed this phenomenon as displayed in Fig. 2h) and k), respectively. The XANES and EXAFS results of H-Ni-silicate indicated nickel metal was embedded on the catalyst surface like H-Cu-silicate because there were different pattern of K-space combination and R-space between fresh and spent H-Ni-silicate as shown in Fig. 2i) and l), respectively. The normalized E-space and normalized 1st derivative of fresh and spent H-Ni-silicate were mainly quite similar with the metal oxides standard reference (NiO2 standard for fresh H-Ni-silicate, and Ni(0) for spent H-Ni-silicate). The reduction reaction over H-Ni-silicate appeared during the 1-butene reaction testing because the mainly percentage of nickel oxides was reduced from NiO2 phase (94.40%) to Ni(0) phase (74.50%) as presented in Table 2. For XANES and EXAFS results summaries of fresh and spent H-M-silicate catalysts, only the substitution of aluminum by iron during the catalyst synthesis could bond the metal in zeolite MFI structure like H-ZSM-5 structure because the aluminum and iron had a similar metal ion (M3+ = Al3+, and Fe3+). While the copper and nickel metal were embedded on zeolite matrix over the catalyst surface because both metals were different metal ion state from M3+ phase; therefore: these metals could not form in the zeolite MFI structure like H-ZSM-5 catalyst. Nevertheless, the reduction reaction occurred during 1-butene reaction because the oxidation state of metal over spent H-M-silicate was reduced when compare with the fresh H-M-silicate and the proposed model of reduction reaction with hydrocarbon over H-M-silicate catalyst presents in Fig. 3 a). 3.2 Catalyst acidity NH3-TPD profile and acid strength of H-M-silicate were described in Fig. 4 a) and Table 3 , respectively. Generally, acid strength of catalyst is divided into three main temperature zones including weak, medium, and strong acid sites [29]. H-ZSM-5 and H-Fe-silicate present three main desorption peaks, associating with weak, medium, and strong acid sites of catalyst, whereas only weak and medium acid sites appeared on H-Cu-silicate and H-Ni-silicate as shown in Fig. 4a). Based on Table 3, the number of total acid site (weak, medium, and strong acid sites) over catalyst surface was H-ZSM-5 > H-Fe-silicate > H-Ni-silicate > H-Cu-silicate. The Brønsted and Lewis acid types present in Fig. 4b), and intensities of these sites are summarized in Table 4 . Based on previous research, two peaks (ca. 1330, and 1620 cm−1) related to Lewis acid site [30,31], while Brønsted acid sites (B1, and B2) associated with bands at ca. 1470, and 1660 cm−1, respectively [16,32–34]. H-ZSM-5 displayed only one main B1 Brønsted acid site at ca. 1470 cm−1, while the B2 Brønsted acid site of H-ZSM-5 catalyst almost disappeared as shown in Fig. 4b). H-Fe-silicate presented one main B1 Brønsted acid site and small B2 Brønsted acid site. For H-Ni-silicate, small peak of B1 and B2 Brønsted acid sites appeared. While only B2 Brønsted acid sites could measure for H-Cu-silicate. The number of B1 Brønsted acid site was H-ZSM-5, H-Fe-silicate, H-Ni-silicate, and H-Cu-silicate (in order of highest to lowest intensity), whereas the number of B2 Brønsted acid site concentration was H-Cu-silicate > H-Ni-silicate > H-Fe-silicate > H-ZSM-5. However, the total Brønsted acid site (B1 + B2) density was the same order of B1 Brønsted acid site intensity as summarized in Table 4. The XANES, EXAFS, and NH3-IR results of H-M-silicate catalyst could be identified the structure of B1 Brønsted acid site. Based on the general structure of Brønsted acid site over H-ZSM-5 catalyst, the Si-OH-Al site was agreed to be a Brønsted acid site [35–37]. Only H-ZSM-5 and H-Fe-silicate indicated major peak representing B1 Brønsted acid site at 1460 cm−1 (NH3-IR result in Fig. 4b)) and the XANES and EXAFS characterizations of H-Fe-silicate presented that the iron metal was the substitute for aluminum during the catalyst synthesis. Therefore, this result suggested that the metal ion, which was detected in the oxidation state of +3, could be formed a Brønsted acid site at 1460 cm−1 as shown in Fig. 3b). The results corresponded with FT-IR spectra of these catalyst in OH stretching region as shown in supplementary material Fig. S6. Based on supplementary material Fig. S6, H-ZSM-5 and H-Fe-silicate presented a peak representing Si-OH-Al [35], and Si-OH-Fe [38] at ca. 3605 cm−1, respectively. Both sites could be assigned to one type of Brønsted acid sites of the catalyst [35,38]. While the XANES and EXAFS results of H-Cu-silicate, and H-Ni-silicate appeared that the oxidation state of metal was not +3, therefore, the peak at 1460 cm−1 of H-Cu-silicate and H-Ni-silicate were almost disappeared by NH3-IR technique. For the N2 adsorption and desorption results and NH3-IR profiles of H-M-silicate catalyst, the location of each Brønsted acid site was proposed. Based on the Table 1 and Fig. 4b), only H-ZSM-5 and H-Fe-silicate were a high ratio of micropore to external surface area of the catalyst and the B1 Brønsted acid (Si-OH-M structure) was mainly outstanding peak of these catalyst; therefore: it implied that B1 Brønsted acid was bonded at micropore surface area of H-M-silicate catalyst. This result was corresponded with previous study which reported that the acid sites (active sites, Si-OH-Al) mainly located in zeolite micropores [39,40]. However, the external surface area of the catalyst was implied to generated B2 Brønsted acid because H-Cu-silicate presented a high external surface area and B2 Brønsted acid was a major part of this catalyst. This proposed model was related to the result of Martin et al., who found that the Si-OH site could be located at external surface of catalyst [36]; therefore: the possible structure of B2 Brønsted acid site was Si-OH site which was one of the Brønsted acid site. 3.3 Catalytic performance test The Brønsted acid site, detected by pyridine-IR technique, has been agreed to be an active site for butene cracking reaction [13,14]. Table 5 demonstrates catalyst performance of H-M-silicate at 500 °C under atmospheric pressure with WHSV = 3 h − 1 (molar ratio of 1-butene and N2 = 65:35). Based on Tables 1, 4, and 5, total Brønsted acid site (NH3-IR) of H-M-silicate, contributing by BET surface area, related to 1-butene conversion of these catalysts. Generally, a bimolecular mechanism of C4 alkenes is applied to describe a main reaction of 1-butene cracking [14,41,42]. This mechanism associated with one carbenium ion of butene and another butene molecule to form various types of octyl carbenium ion, then cracked into light alkenes [43,44]. The hydrogen transfer reaction occurred to transform like alkenes to corresponding light alkanes and aromatic compounds, coke precursors, were built by a dehydrogenation-aromatization reaction [45,46]. In this study, all these reactions were called an oligomerization-cracking reaction route of 1-butene reaction. Another reaction route was isomerization of butene route and double bond isomerization to form cis- or trans-2-butenes, which was an easiest reaction of all reactions in butene cracking reaction. Therefore, the product distribution in each route of 1-butene reaction (oligomerization-cracking and isomerization of butene routes) is summarized in Table 5. Based on Table 5, the H-ZSM-5 catalyst promoted a highest product in oligomerization-cracking route, when compared with the other metallosilicate in this study and the order of product selectivity in this route over this metallosilicate catalyst was H-Fe-silicate > H-Ni-silicate > H-Cu-silicate. While the number of product selectivity in isomerization of butene route over metallosilicate catalyst was H-Cu-silicate, H-Ni-silicate, H-Fe-silicate, and H-ZSM-5 (in order of highest to lowest). A correlation between Brønsted acid type (B1 and B2) and product selectivity in each route of 1-butene reaction (oligomerization-cracking and isomerization of butene routes) over H-M-silicate is display in Fig. 5 . Based on Fig. 5, the number of B1 Brønsted acid site correlated with oligomerization-cracking product, whereas butene isomer selectivities increased when B2 Brønsted acid site raised up. Therefore, B1 Brønsted acid site was an active site of the product in the oligomerization-cracking route, whereas the butene isomer selectivities occurred on B2 Brønsted acid site of the catalyst. Based on this result, B1 Brønsted acid site, Si-OH-M structure, over micropore surface area of catalyst was higher acid strength that B2 Brønsted acid site (Si-OH) over external surface area of catalyst because of product distribution of 1 -butene reaction and it was corresponded with previous study which found that Si-OH-Al site was a strong Brønsted acid site [47]. For the summary, a proposed mechanism of butene reaction relating with type of Brønsted acid site of the catalyst is shown in Scheme 1 . Not only Brønsted acid site over the catalyst surface contributed the product formation in the reaction, but redox site over the catalyst also interacted with the C-H bond of hydrocarbon to generate various products in the reaction [48]. As shown in Fig. 3a), the metal of the H-M-silicate, which was the same metal oxide behavior as presented in XANES and EXAFS results, was reduced the oxidation state after interacting with the hydrocarbon molecule. The hydrocarbon transferred the electron to the metal and formed another molecule after contacting the metal on the catalyst surface. This proposed model was corresponded with the previous research [49–51]. The previous studies found that the synthesized catalyst with metal loading generated redox site which related various reactions: isomerization [51], cracking [49], and dehydrogenation [50] reactions. Fig. 6 displays about stability and product distributions (ethylene, propylene, and butene isomers selectivities) of metallosilicate catalysts after 300 min of TOS. Based on Fig. 6a), catalyst deactivation of H-ZSM-5 was 3.43% after 300 min of TOS, while H-M-silicate (H-Fe-silicate, and H-Ni-silicate) presented a higher deactivation rate than H-ZSM-5 at 9.24%, and 26.77%, respectively. However, H-Cu-silicate could be shown the best catalyst stability of this study at 2.63% after 300 min of TOS. Fig. 6b) and c) present ethylene and propylene selectivities of metallosilicate catalysts throughout 300 min of TOS. At the end of the reaction stability test in this study (300 min of TOS), the order of ethylene and propylene selectivities was H-ZSM-5 > H-Fe-silicate > H-Ni-silicate > H-Cu-silicate as same as this order at the initial of this reaction because the ethylene and propylene products were generated from oligomerization-cracking route which corresponded with the number of B1 Brønsted acid site as displayed in Fig. 6b) and c). While the butene isomers selectivities of metallosilicate catalysts after 300 min of TOS is shown in Fig. 6d). The number of butene isomers selectivities of these catalysts at 300 min of TOS was higher than the initial butene isomers selectivities at this reaction. The order of this group of products was H-Cu-silicate > H-Ni-silicate > H-Fe-silicate > H-ZSM-5 throughout 300 min of TOS because the butene isomers products were generated by B2 Brønsted acid site. To further describe about catalyst deactivation of this reaction, TPO technique is applied to identify amount of coke during 1-butene reaction throughout 300 min of TOS. Supplementary material Fig. S7 and supplementary material table S3 present TPO profiles and weight percentage of carbon content of H-M-silicate catalyst after the reaction, respectively. Generally, TPO profiles could be divided into three main zones attributing to absorbing saturated coke (250–450 °C, low zone), coke conversion from acid-catalyzed reaction (450–650 °C, middle zone), and high ordered filamentous coke (above 700 °C, high zone), respectively [52]. Based on supplementary material Fig. S7, the order of main oxidation peak over H-M-silicate catalyst was H-ZSM-5, H-Ni-silicate, H-Fe-silicate, and H-Cu-silicate (in order of highest to lowest temperature peak center). The TPO profile of H-Cu-silicate indicated a main peak range in low zone of oxidation temperature and this profile also related with middle zone a little. Main component of TPO profile over H-Fe-silicate and H-Ni-silicate were in the range of low and middle zones of oxidation temperature peaks, whereas TPO profile of H-Fe-silicate also appeared a little coke type in the high temperature zone. Only middle and high zones of oxidation temperature were observed in TPO profile of H-ZSM-5. The deactivation rate of H-M-silicate catalyst in 1-butene reaction throughout 300 min of TOS correlated with the number of weight percentage of carbon content as displayed in supplementary material Fig. S7 and supplementary material table S3. Therefore, the carbon weight percentage detected by TPO technique was a main cause of the catalyst deactivation for H-M-silicate in this reaction because carbon content was a coke precursor to block the active site of catalyst (Brønsted acid site). 4 Conclusion The synthesized metallosilicate catalysts (H-M-silicate, when M = Al, Fe, Cu, and Ni) with Si/metal molar ratio of 20 presented MFI structure. For H-ZSM-5 catalyst, the tetrahedral framework Al site was dominant over fresh H-ZSM-5. However, octahedral framework Al site was formed over spent H-ZSM-5 because of the loss of tetrahedral framework Al site. Based on XANES and EXAFS results, only H-Fe-silicate indicated the iron could bond in MFI structure as same as the aluminum bonding in zeolite framework of H-ZSM-5. While the nickel in H-Ni-silicate and copper in H-Cu-silicate embedded in zeolite matrix over the catalyst surface. After the reaction testing, the reduction reaction occurred over the metal site of metallosilicate catalyst because of the lower oxidation state of metal over spent catalyst when compared with the fresh one. The NH3-IR result suggested that there were two Brønsted acid sites over theses catalysts at ca. 1470 and 1660 cm−1 representing B1 and B2 Brønsted acid sites, respectively. The B1 Brønsted acid site over micropore surface area of catalyst, which was correlated with Si-OH-M structure of the catalyst, was an active site for the oligomerization-cracking products of 1-butene reaction and this site was dominant in H-ZSM-5 and H-Fe-silicate. While the main product distribution of H-Cu-silicate and H-Ni-silicate was the isomers of butene corresponding with the number of B2 Brønsted acid site (Si-OH site) over external surface area of catalyst. Therefore, the acid strength of B2 Brønsted acid site was weaker than B1 Brønsted acid site. The coke formation was directly proportional to the deactivation of metallosilicate catalyst in this study. coredata.dc:description: The metallosilicate catalysts (H-M-silicate, when M = Al, Fe, Cu, and Ni and Si/metal = 20) were synthesized and characterized by XRD, SEM-EDX, XRF, N2 adsorption and desorption, 27Al MAS NMR, XANES, EXAFS, NH3-TPD, NH3-IR, and TPO methods to investigate the effect of transition metals substitution in zeolite structure for 1-butene reaction. Only Fe3+ of H-Fe-silicate bonded in the MFI structure like H-ZSM-5, whereas transition metals of H-Cu-silicate and H-Ni-silicate embedded in zeolite matrix over catalyst surface; therefore: the reduction reaction occurred over metal of H-M-silicate catalyst during the reaction. There were two different roles of Brønsted acid site, detected by NH3-IR (B1 at ca. 1470 cm−1 and B2 at ca. 1660 cm−1). The B1 Brønsted acid site over micropore surface of catalyst (Si-OH-M) favored oligomerization-cracking route of 1-butene reaction, while butene isomerization route reacted on B2 Brønsted acid site (Si-OH) over external surface of catalyst (Acid strength: B1 > B2)
coredata.dc:title: A study of the acidity on catalyst surface to control 1-butene reaction mechanism of metallosilicate catalysts
